security_findings.description:
The [California Online Privacy Protection Act](http://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/codes_displaySection.xhtml?lawCode=BPC&sectionNum=22575) (CALOPPA) requires publishers to provide a valid privacy policy on the App's Google Play page, especially if the App is requesting sensitive user or device information.

The App has requested one or more of the following sensitive permissions:

* `android.permission.CAMERA`
* `android.permission.RECORD_AUDIO`
* `android.permission.READ_PHONE_STATE`
* `android.permission.GET_ACCOUNTS`
* `android.permission.READ_CONTACTS`
 
However, the App does not have a privacy policy on its Google Play page. If a privacy policy is not published on the App's Google Play page:

* Google will limit the visibility of the App, up to and including removal from Google Play
* CALOPPA may subject the App to fines "up to [$2,500 for each time](https://www.privacyandsecuritymatters.com/2012/11/californias-ag-puts-mobile-apps-on-notice/) the App was downloaded"

Furthermore, the Attorney General's office in California has released an online complaint form for end-users to report violations at any time, available at [https://oag.ca.gov/privacy/caloppa/complaint-form](https://oag.ca.gov/privacy/caloppa/complaint-form).

A list of Apps that have already been blocked by Google Play because of this issue can be found [here](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/41257387/policy-issue-google-play).
security_findings.recommendation:
Create a privacy policy for the App and ensure that it is reviewed and approved by the legal team. Then, add the privacy policy to the App's Google Play page by following these instructions:

1. In the Google Play Developer Console, select the App
2. Click on "Store Listing" on the left side
3. Scroll to the bottom and locate "Privacy Policy"
4. Insert the HTML link to your privacy policy in the text box
security_findings.title: Google Play Blocker: Absent Privacy Policy on Google Play

security_finding_targets.text: Absent Privacy Policy on the App's Google Play Page

compliance_policy_references.markdown: M1 - Improper Platform Usage
Free security features offered by the toolchain are activated (MSTG-CODE-9)

security_findings.description:
The App does not ensure that it is running on a device that has an up-to-date Android Security Provider.

Because the Security Provider is responsible for providing secure network communications to the Apps on the device, running the App on a device with an outdated Security Provider could expose it to networks attacks, for example allowing an attacker on the network to decrypt and compromise an App's SSL/TLS traffic without the user knowing. 

For example, Google Play services version 5.0 fixed a vulnerability that was discovered in OpenSSL ([CVE-2014-0224](web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2014-0224)) that can leave Apps open to a "man-in-the-middle" attack. However, the fix is only deployed on the device if its Security Provider was properly updated.

More information is available on the ["Updating Your Security Provider to Protect Against SSL Exploits"](https://developer.android.com/training/articles/security-gms-provider.html#patching) of the Android developer website.
security_findings.recommendation:
The Google Play services provide [an `ProviderInstaller.installIfNeeded()` method](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/security/ProviderInstaller#installIfNeeded(android.content.Context)) that will ensure that the device that is secured against vulnerabilities and that the Security Provider is up to date.

Leverage this method in order to perform the check during the App's startup; the following cases need to be handled:

* If the device's Provider is successfully updated (or is already up-to-date), the method will return normally.
* If the device's Google Play services library is out of date, the method will throw an `GooglePlayServicesRepairableException`. The App can then catch this exception and show the user an appropriate dialog box to update Google Play services.
* If an error occurs, the method will throw a `GooglePlayServicesNotAvailableException` to indicate that it is unable to update the Provider. The App can then catch the exception and choose an appropriate course of action.
security_findings.title: Enable Verification on Android Security Provider

security_finding_targets.text: The App's lack of a mechanism for enforcing an up-to-date Android Security Provider via `ProviderInstaller.installIfNeeded(context);`

security_findings.description:
Allowing WebViews to access content from the App's private storage and the external storage may lead to unauthorized file access.
In most cases, WebViews do not need to access the file system. Also, Restricting file system access does not prevent an
App from loading files from the Assets and resources, those files are still accessible using `file:///android_asset` and `file:///android_res`.
security_findings.description_intro: The following WebViews can access and load content from the file system:
security_findings.recommendation:
File system access is allowed by default and can be restricted by explicitly setting the [`setAllowFileAccess`](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/webkit/WebSettings.html#setAllowFileAccess(boolean)) 
method to false.
security_findings.secure_code:
Explicitly set [`setAllowFileAccess`](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/webkit/WebSettings.html#setAllowFileAccess(boolean)) method to false. 
`webview.getSettings().setAllowFileAccess(false);`
security_findings.title: File Access Enabled Within WebView

compliance_policy_references.markdown: M5 - Insufficient Cryptography
Downgrade to Insecure Protocols (MTC ID:  CEL-3)
The app uses proven implementations of cryptographic primitives (MSTG-CRYPTO-2)

security_findings.description:
Using ECB as the mode of operation for AES encryption can leak information about the content of the encrypted data, because identical plaintext blocks are encrypted into identical ciphertext blocks. Consequently, ECB does not hide data patterns well and does not provide proper message confidentiality; this is demonstrated in the screenshot which shows how patterns can leak information about the plaintext.

As a consequence, ECB mode is not recommended for use in cryptographic protocols at all.

The following configuration modes imply the usage of insecure AES/ECB modes: 

* `"AES"`  defaults to  `"AES/ECB"`
* `"AES/ECB/NoPadding"`
* `"AES/ECB/PKCS5Padding"`
* `"AES/ECB/ISO10126Padding"`

As part of Google's App Security Improvement Program, Google Play has 
[begun to warn Apps](https://support.google.com/faqs/answer/10046138) that are using weak modes of encryption.
security_findings.description_intro: The following code locations defined within the App perform AES encryption using the insecure ECB mode:
security_findings.recommendation:
As raw cryptographic algorithms are difficult to use securely due to subtle implementation flaws such as weak modes of operation or timing attacks, avoid directly using low-level cryptographic APIs (such as `javax.crypto.Cipher`) to encrypt sensitive data. 

Instead, consider relying on a high-level cryptographic library such as:

[Jetpack Security crypto library](https://developer.android.com/topic/security/data.md) which provides abstractions for encrypting Files and SharedPreferences objects. 
This library promotes the use of AndroidKeyStore while using safe and [well-known cryptographic primitives](https://github.com/google/tink/blob/master/docs/PRIMITIVES.md). 

If AES needs to be used directly, use `“AES/GCM/NoPadding”` instead of the aforementioned insecure mode.
security_findings.title: Google Play Warning: Unsafe Cryptographic Encryption Mode Usage

compliance_policy_references.markdown: The app protects itself against screen overlay attacks (MSTG-PLATFORM-5)

security_findings.description:
In a TapJacking attack, the attacker hijacks the user's taps and tricks the user into performing an action the user did not intend. 
A malicious third party App installed on the device creates an overlay on top of the vulnerable App. When the naive user taps on the overlay, the taps are passed on to the vulnerable App.

Also, To create overlays on top of all other Apps, these third party Apps need to have SYSTEM_ALERT_WINDOW permission. 
From Android 6.1, if the user side loads an App (non-Google Play Store App), the user must explicitly grant this permission through the permission management screen in Android settings. This need for user intervention reduces the chances of a malicious App performing a TapJacking attack. That said any App with the 
SYSTEM_ALERT_WINDOW can display an active overlay screen, listen for taps, and perform a TapJacking Attack.

All versions of the Android OS before Android 8.1(API 27) leave apps vulnerable to TapJacking attacks.
security_findings.recommendation:
There are 2 ways to prevent TapJacking attacks on your App:

1. Google has released [security patches](https://source.android.com/security/bulletin/android-11) for Android versions 8.1 and above. Provided the security patches are installed, 
updating the minimum SDK version of the App to 27 (Android 8.1) will make sure the App will not run on vulnerable versions of Android.


2. If increasing the minimum SDK version is not a feasible option, you may use Android’s touch filter to defend against such attacks. There are multiple ways to enable touch filtering: 

* Calling [`setFilterTouchesWhenObscured(True)`](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/view/View.html#setFilterTouchesWhenObscured(boolean))
signals the framework to discard touches when another visible window obscures the view's window.

* Set the `android:filterTouchesWhenObscured` layout attribute to "true" signals the framework to discard touches when another visible window obscures the view's window.

* Implement `onFilterTouchEventForSecurity()` in the App to filter the touch event to apply security policies.

* Check for the `MotionEvent.FLAG_WINDOW_IS_OBSCURED` flag in the `onTouch()` handler of the view as shown in the security code below. 

These methods will prevent your App from getting touches when another App is obscuring it.
security_findings.title: App Views are Vulnerable to TapJacking

security_findings.description:
This permission allows your App to access all of the User's data from third-party apps, including the ability to read media files created by other Apps on the device.

Post Android 10 (API 29), [Scoped Storage](https://developer.android.com/training/data-storage#scoped-storage) was introduced to ensure that an App is only able 
to access files and media created by itself, not others, which are implemented via the [Storage Access Framework](https://developer.android.com/guide/topics/providers/document-provider) or the [Media Store API](https://developer.android.com/training/data-storage/shared/media).
security_findings.recommendation:
Remove the `READ_EXTERNAL_STORAGE` permission.

Further Reading:
Android’s Data and File Storage Overview can be found on [https://developer.android.com/training/data-storage](https://developer.android.com/training/data-storage)
security_findings.secure_code:
```
Remove the following line from the AndroidManifest.xml file. 

<uses-permission android:name="android.permission.READ_EXTERNAL_STORAGE"/>
```
security_findings.title: Read Access Requested to User's Private Media

compliance_policy_references.markdown: M1 - Improper Platform Usage

security_findings.description:
Starting with Android 13, the system will [display any text](https://developer.android.com/about/versions/13/behavior-changes-all#copy-sensitive-content) that is copied in a popover UI on the user's screen. If the user has copied sensitive content (such as a password), this can lead to sensitive data exposure. 

To mitigate this risk factor, Android 13 introduces a new flag, [`EXTRA_IS_SENSITIVE`](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/content/ClipDescription#EXTRA_IS_SENSITIVE), that can be applied to data copied to the clipboard. If this flag is applied, the system will treat the data copied to the clipboard as sensitive and will refrain from displaying it on the user's screen. 

Therefore, when the App is running on Android 13, it must mark any sensitive content copied to the clipboard as such, to prevent data exposure to attackers in the user's vicinity. Note that this UI applies to any App running on Android 13, and is presented regardless of the App's target API version. Therefore, we recommend that all applications mark sensitive clipboard content as necessary.
security_findings.description_intro: The following code locations save data to the device clipboard:
security_findings.recommendation: If the App copies any sensitive data to the clipboard, mark the data as sensitive to the system to prevent unnecessary data exposure. As this UI is presented on any device running Android 13, regardless of the App's underlying target API version, implement this mitigation even if the App is targeting a lower API version.
security_findings.title: Sensitive Content Exposed via Clipboard

compliance_policy_references.markdown: Exploit OS Vulnerability (MTC ID:  APP-26)

security_findings.description:
The App is vulnerable to Mobile Phishing by not leveraging the [Play Integrity API](https://developer.android.com/google/play/integrity), a free Google Play service that will ensure the App was downloaded legitimately from the Google Play Store (instead of 175+ fraudulent stores detected by Mobile Phishing). Without this protection, any phisher can:

1. Download your app (.apk or .aab binary) from Google Play.
2. Post the .apk/aab on any third-party app store, such as [Aptoide](https://en.aptoide.com/), [AppChina](https://appchina.com/), and 175+ more.
3. Phish your users similar to how Email Phishing.
security_findings.recommendation:
Enable the Play Integrity API in order to reduce the likelihood of Mobile Phishing: 

* If the Play Integrity API reports that the environment is legitimate, proceed with the App's regular flow.
* If the Play Integrity API reports that the environment is illegitimate, choose between one of the following options, based on how critical the device's integrity is to the App's security:
  1. Log the failure server-side (for security metrics) and proceed with the App's regular flow.
  2. Log the failure server-side (for security metrics) and prevent sensitive APIs and flows from being accessed (e.g. change password, credit card payment, account transfers, photos access, etc.).
  3. Log the failure server-side (for security metrics) and block any usage of the App.

More information on the Play Integrity API can be found on [the Android developer website](https://developer.android.com/google/play/integrity).
security_findings.title: App Vulnerable to Mobile Phishing

security_finding_targets.text: The App's lack of the Play Integrity API via `IntegrityManager.requestIntegrityToken()`

security_finding_targets.text: `android.permission.ACCESS_COARSE_LOCATION`: Allows an app to access approximate location derived from network location sources such as cell towers and Wi-Fi. User's location is considered to be private and should be collected only when there is a legitimate use case.

`android.permission.ACCESS_FINE_LOCATION`: Allows an app to access precise location from location sources such as GPS, cell towers, and Wi-Fi. For most applications that require location information `ACCESS_COARSE_LOCATION` is sufficient. `ACCESS_COARSE_LOCATION` allows an app to access approximate location derived from network location sources such as cell towers and Wi-Fi. User's location is considered to be private and should be collected only when there is a legitimate use case.
`android.permission.READ_LOGS`: Allows an application to read the low-level system log files.Not for use by third-party applications, because Log entries can contain the user's private information.
`android.permission.USE_CREDENTIALS`: Allows the app to request authentication tokens

`android.permission.READ_CALENDAR`: This permission allows an application to read user's complete calendar data. An application can also read calendar created by other applications and the user. In most scenarios an application only requires the `WRITE_CALENDAR` permission.

`android.permission.READ_PHONE_STATE`: This permission allows read only access to phone state. Developers, usually use this permission to detect when the user receives a call. However, this permission also provides the application access to sensitive hardware identifiers such as the IMEI, SimSerialNumber, SubscriberID.
`android.permission.CAMERA`: Allows an application to access the camera device.

compliance_policy_references.markdown: All inputs from external sources and the user are validated and if necessary sanitized (MSTG-PLATFORM-2)

security_findings.description:
Android provides the `java.util.zip` package, which contains classes such as `ZipInputStream` that enable an App to read, create and modify ZIP archives. When using this API to unzip an archive, it does not protect against file names in the archive that trigger a path traversal (such as `../..`). This allows a malicious archive to overwrite files within the App's container when the archive gets unzipped.

The [Zipperdown](https://zipperdown.appscan.io/) exploit leverages this issue to potentially allow a remote attacker who has the ability to inject a malicious archive into the App (for example because of unencrypted connections initiated by the App) to overwrite files. Depending on the App's functionality and how the API is being used, it may allow the attacker to perform a remote code execution attack against the App, and thereby get full access to the App's data.

Security concerns regarding the `ZipInputStream` API have been [extensively discussed before](https://wiki.sei.cmu.edu/confluence/display/java/IDS04-J.+Safely+extract+files+from+ZipInputStream), but the Zipperdown research team has released a search engine to expose Apps that are using the `ZipInputStream` API at [https://zipperdown.appscan.io/](https://zipperdown.appscan.io/).
security_findings.description_intro: The following Java or Kotlin classes within the App unzip archives in an insecure manner and might be vulnerable to the ZipperDown vulnerability:
security_findings.recommendation: When unzipping an archive, always validate the compressed files' paths and reject any path that has a path traversal (such as `../..`). Simply looking for `..` characters in the compressed file's path may not be enough to prevent path traversal issues, and a more robust approach is described in the "Secure Code" section below.
security_findings.title: App Leverages Zip API Vulnerable to Zipperdown

security_findings.description:
Monitoring an App's performance on real user's device provides valuable information to the developers for 
troubleshooting bugs and improving Apps performance. 
However, if the performance metrics are not properly anonymized it may contain sensitive information such as user's 
personal information or tracking identifiers that should never be disclosed to developers or testers in the organization.
This is critical for an App to remain compliant with data privacy policies while monitoring for performance. 

Technical Performance Metrics include: 

* Stability
* App launch time
* UI screen transition speeds
* Network performance
* Logic execution speeds
* Battery consumption
* CPU usage
* Memory usage
* User Session Recording
security_findings.description_intro: The following locations in the App are collecting performance metrics:
security_findings.recommendation:
Properly anonymize the performance metrics and redact any sensitive information prior to sending it over to the server side. 

Google Play is adding a [new Data privacy and security section](https://support.google.com/googleplay/android-developer/answer/9934569) to the User Data policy where developers 
must provide accurate information related to personal or sensitive user data their apps collect, use, or share. 

As a requirement to this policy, if an App is collecting performance metrics and sending it over to the server side, it needs 
to report this action to Google Play and also clearly mention this in the Apps privacy policy.
security_findings.title: App is Collecting Performance Metrics

compliance_policy_references.markdown: Exploit OS Vulnerability (MTC ID:  APP-26)

security_findings.description:
The App is not leveraging [the Play Integrity API](https://developer.android.com/google/play/integrity), a free Google Play service for providing key security guarantees to the App. A positive status from Play Integrity provides the following guarantees:

* The App is genuine and has no signs of tampering.
* The App was downloaded legitimately from the Google Play Store (instead of 175+ fraudulent stores detected by Mobile Phishing). 
* The App is running on a genuine Android device that uses Google Play Services.

The Play Integrity API is intended to protect the App from fraudulent interactions by providing a Google-signed attestation that the device is secure. This can allow the App to only present key interactions or sensitive information if it can be sure that it's running in a secure context. 

Depending on the outcome of the Play Integrity check, an App can either prevent itself from executing or block sensitive APIs from being invoked (such as the "change password" API).
security_findings.recommendation:
Enable the Play Integrity API in order to assess the integrity of the app and safety of the user's device. The following features should be enabled: 

* If the Play Integrity API reports that the environment is legitimate, proceed with the App's regular flow.
* If the Play Integrity API reports that the environment is illegitimate, choose between one of the following options, based on how critical the device's integrity is to the App's security:
  1. Log the failure server-side (for security metrics) and proceed with the App's regular flow.
  2. Log the failure server-side (for security metrics) and prevent sensitive APIs and flows from being accessed (e.g. change password, credit card payment, account transfers, photos access, etc.).
  3. Log the failure server-side (for security metrics) and block any usage of the App.

More information on the Play Integrity API can be found on [the Android developer website](https://developer.android.com/google/play/integrity).
security_findings.title: Absent Integrity: App Protection Missing

security_finding_targets.text: The App's lack of the Play Integrity API via `IntegrityManager.requestIntegrityToken()`

security_findings.description: Apps and services targeting Android 14 must use [context registered receivers](https://developer.android.com/guide/components/broadcasts#context-registered-receivers) to lockdown all broadcast from all other apps on the device. This requirement helps protect apps from security vulnerabilities by leveraging the features for these receivers introduced in Android 13. On previous versions of Android, any app on the device could send an unprotected broadcast to any app on the device.
security_findings.description_intro: The following context registered receivers have not been locked down, which allows any app on the device to send an unprotected broadcast to the App and dynamically register its receiver (unless that receiver was previously guarded by a signature permission):
security_findings.recommendation: Update the App's `BroadcastReceiver` registrations by specifying the exported behavior. Choose whether the broadcast receiver should be exported and visible to other apps on the device. If the App's receiver is listening for broadcasts sent from the system or from other apps - even other apps that are owned by the same organization - use the `RECEIVER_EXPORTED` flag. If the App's receiver is listening only for broadcasts sent by your app, use the `RECEIVER_NOT_EXPORTED` flag only.
security_findings.title: System Wide Exposure of Broadcasts Receivers (Absent RECEIVER_NOT_EXPORTED)

security_findings.description:
The App contains references to Phone Number without specifying the corresponding [Data Safety Tag](https://support.google.com/googleplay/android-developer/answer/10787469?hl=en). All developers must declare how they collect and handle user data for the apps they publish on Google Play, and provide details about how they protect this data through security practices like encryption. Failure to report data collections may result in Google Play warnings during the App Review process.

Even if the App does not use Phone Number APIs at runtime, string references to Phone Number will be detected by Google and necessitate inclusion of Phone Number in the Data Safety report.
security_findings.description_intro: The following strings in the App reference Phone Numbers:
security_findings.recommendation:
If the App does not require Phone Number access but an embedded SDK contains references to Phone Numbers, consider removing the SDK or asking the SDK vendor for a build that does not include code to access the data.

If collection of a Phone Number is required for App functionality, follow Google's guidelines for filling out the App's [Data Safety Form](https://support.google.com/googleplay/android-developer/answer/10787469?hl=en#in_play_console) on Google Play Console. Additionally, ensure the privacy policy documents the collection of phone number.

Data Theorem's [PlayStore Answers](https://www.securetheorem.com/mobile/android/privacy) toolkit can automatically generate a Data Safety report which can be uploaded directly to the Play Console.

security_findings.description:
The App is requesting permission to read data from the device's SD card via the following entry in its Android Manifest:

`<uses-permission android:name="android.permission.READ_EXTERNAL_STORAGE" />`

In historical versions of Android, utilizing the `READ_EXTERNAL_STORAGE` permission was the sanctioned way to access certain user media, such as photos and videos.

However, as of [Android 13](https://developer.android.com/about/versions/13/behavior-changes-13#granular-media-permissions), the OS now provides more tightly scoped permissions that only allow access to particular types of data that might reside on external storage.

For example, if the App's use case for reading external storage is to fetch user photos, the App should instead use the new `READ_MEDIA_IMAGES` permission, or use the [Photo Picker](https://developer.android.com/training/data-storage/shared/photopicker) API which requires no App permissions.
security_findings.recommendation: Unless the App has a need to read files in general, migrate from the `READ_EXTERNAL_STORAGE` permission to a more tightly scoped permission which restricts the amount of data that's exposed to the App surface and which more clearly conveys the intent of the App's data access.
security_findings.title: Remove Deprecated Storage Access

security_findings.description:
Advertisement Identifier is leaking to a 3rd Party OSS/SDK. Advertisement identifiers such as the [Android Advertising ID](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/ads/identifier/AdvertisingIdClient) or the [iOS IDFA](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/adsupport/asidentifiermanager?language=objc) are used to track a device across App installations.

On both iOS and Android, advertisement identifiers and can be disabled by the user in their device's privacy settings.

Details about the user's device, such as the screen size or the OS version are generally used to provide stats about the App's user base, and to improve the App's user experience.
However, such data can also be used by third parties to fingerprint the user's device, when combined with other data points (such as the user's location).

During dynamic analysis, Data Theorem’s analyzer checks for leaks in several areas, including, but not limited to, the following items:
OS Version, Device Manufacturer, Device Type, Device Model, Device Name, Device Platform, TimeZone, Locale, Build ID, Bootloader Version, Baseband Version, Fingerprint, MAC Address, IDFA, Android ID, IMEI, IMSI, Phone Number, Carrier Name, Carrier Code, Carrier ID, SIM Serial Number, Local IP Address, SSID, BSSID, etc.

[//]: # "data dump tag"
security_findings.description_intro: The App is leaking advertisement identifiers to one or more of the following destinations:
security_findings.recommendation:
Due to GDPR and CCPA, any data leaked to 3rd parties that may include user NPI (Nonpublic Personal Information) and PII (Personally Identifiable Information) must be documented in the App’s privacy policy. 

* Option 1: If the OSS/SDK is required, document the data sharing activity above in the App’s privacy policy

* Option 2: If the OSS/SDK is not required, remove it asap and insert the SDK on the “Banned” category within the Policy Configuration menu to avoid future data leaks.
security_findings.title: Advertisement Identifier Leaked to 3rd Party OSS/SDK

security_findings.description:
Weak SSL/TLS cipher suites rely on key length of 56 bits or fewer, which are vulnerable to brute force attacks that would only take hours, and should therefore never be used nor enabled.

Additionally, while most clients (including browsers and mobile Apps) would not actually use weak cipher suites even if the server supports them, researchers have discovered in March 2015 a man-in-the-middle attack that can force SSL connections to use some of these weak cipher suites.

The attack was dubbed "Factoring RSA EXPORT Keys" or "FREAK" and affects numerous SSL clients including Android, iOS, Windows and OpenSSL. More information about this attack is available at [http://blog.cryptographyengineering.com/2015/03/attack-of-week-freak-or-factoring-nsa.html](http://blog.cryptographyengineering.com/2015/03/attack-of-week-freak-or-factoring-nsa.html).
security_findings.description_intro: The following SSL/TLS servers have enabled support for at least one weak cipher suite:
security_findings.recommendation:
Disable weak cipher suites across all the App's server endpoints. Guidelines on secure server-side TLS configurations are available on [Mozilla's "Server Side TLS" page](https://wiki.mozilla.org/Security/Server_Side_TLS). 

Additionally, regularly monitor and validate the deployed SSL/TLS configuration on the App's server endpoints using tools such as [SSLyze](https://github.com/nabla-c0d3/sslyze) or [SSL Labs](https://www.ssllabs.com/ssltest/).
security_findings.title: Server Supports Weak SSL Cipher Suites

security_findings.description:
The affected servers do not return their SSL certificate's revocation status information via OCSP Stapling. 

OCSP stapling is a feature that can be enabled in most web servers to provide clients (such as browsers or mobile Apps) connecting to the server over HTTPS with the information needed to ensure that the certificate has not been revoked. Certificates can be revoked for a variety of reasons, including the compromise of the SSL key or when a certificate was mistakenly issued. Giving HTTPS clients the ability to check for revocation can mitigate the impact of invalid or compromised certificates, in specific attack scenarios.

Additionally, Apple has mentioned OCSP Stapling as a security mechanism that should now be deployed on mobile endpoints, in the "[Your Apps and Evolving Network Security Standards](https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2017/701/)" session of the WWDC 2017 conference and the "[What is New in Security](https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2016/706)" session of the WWDC 2016 conference:

> "OCSP Stapling is a standard that has been out for a couple of years, but we think that now is the time for folks to actually move to it and start adopting it because support for it is now quite widespread."

This could imply that OCSP Stapling will eventually become a requirement for iOS Apps to be accepted on the App Store.
security_findings.description_intro: The following mobile endpoints being accessed by the App at runtime do not support OCSP Stapling:
security_findings.recommendation: Update the affected mobile endpoints’ configuration to enable support for OCSP Stapling. Most modern web servers including [Apache and nginx](https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-configure-ocsp-stapling-on-apache-and-nginx) support stapling.
security_findings.title: Server Lacks OCSP Stapling

security_findings.description:
The App or its SDKs have embedded a permission to use the Advertising ID, which is used by advertisers to cross correlate user devices for targeted advertising, such as location tracking and demographic data. In order to stay compliant with regulatory compliance efforts, Google will phase out the `AD_ID` in Android 13 *unless* the App or its SDKs declare a permission for it.

`com.google.android.gms.permission.AD_ID`

If your developers did not insert this permission, then one of the SDKs has embedded it in the App. Any SDK that wishes to target ads to your users can declare this permission in the SDK’s library manifest, which will be merged with your App’s main manifest even if you don’t explicitly declare the permission in your App’s main manifest.

notes.text:
https://snapfish-llc.atlassian.net/browse/ANDROID-4550
plan is to keep AD_ID since appsflyer requires it

security_findings.recommendation:
Unless your App needs to target users across Apps or devices, remove the `AD_ID` permission and use the [App set ID](https://developer.android.com/training/articles/app-set-id) instead. App set ID is a unique identifier that can still be used for marketing without being intrusive to your users in regard to their behavior across Apps or devices. Also, if the permission was inserted by an SDK embedded in your App, include the below element in your manifest instead.

```xml
<uses-permission android:name="com.google.android.gms.permission.AD_ID"
 tools:node="remove"/>
```
security_findings.secure_code:
Prevent the use of targeted advertising of your users across Apps and devices as well as preventing third party SDKs [merging](https://developer.android.com/studio/build/manifest-merge#node_markers) such permissions by inserting the following in your manifest file: 

```xml
<uses-permission android:name="com.google.android.gms.permission.AD_ID"
 tools:node="remove"/>
```

security_findings.description:
TLS 1.0 is a legacy protocol, which has been found to be vulnerable to numerous attacks since it was released.

Such attacks include the _POODLE_ vulnerability, which was discovered in 2014 [by the Google security team](http://googleonlinesecurity.blogspot.com/2014/10/this-poodle-bites-exploiting-ssl-30.html), as well as other flaws affecting both on the protocol's key exchange mechanism and on the encryption schemes it supports.

A summary of most of the vulnerabilities the TLS 1.0 protocol is vulnerable to is available in [RFC 7457](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7457).

Most mobile Apps would usually negotiate a stronger version of the protocol (such as TLS 1.2), making this issue difficult to exploit in the context of an App. However, specific browsers (such as Firefox) accessing the vulnerable endpoints may be exposed [through protocol downgrade attacks](https://blog.qualys.com/ssllabs/2014/10/15/ssl-3-is-dead-killed-by-the-poodle-attack).

Lastly, TLS v1.0 is no longer acceptable for PCI compliance due to the vulnerabilities mentioned above (such as _POODLE_), as stated in [Appendix A2 of the PCI DSS Requirements](https://www.pcisecuritystandards.org/documents/PCI_DSS_v3-2.pdf):

> "After June 30, 2018, all entities must have stopped use of SSL/early TLS as a security control, and use only secure versions of the protocol"
security_findings.description_intro: The following SSL/TLS servers accessed by the App at runtime have enabled the TLS 1.0 protocol:

notes.text: we do not control 3rd party servers
we do not control 3rd party servers

security_findings.recommendation:
Disable TLS v1.0 across all the App's endpoints, and require TLS 1.2 or later. It should be noted that disabling TLS v1.0 will also prevent legacy clients from connecting to the endpoints.

Guidelines on secure server-side TLS configurations are available in [the Mozilla Server Side TLS guides](https://wiki.mozilla.org/Security/Server_Side_TLS).

Additionally, regularly monitor and validate the deployed SSL/TLS configuration on the App's server endpoints using tools such as [SSLyze](https://github.com/nabla-c0d3/sslyze) or [SSL Labs](https://www.ssllabs.com/ssltest/).
security_findings.title: Server Supports Insecure TLS 1.0

security_findings.description:
GCP API keys hard-coded in the App's code can be easily extracted and used by attackers for nefarious purposes. This 
exposure of the API keys could lead to unexpected charges and quota changes in your App's account. 

As part of Google's App Security Improvement Program, Google Play has 
[begun to warn Apps](https://support.google.com/faqs/answer/9287711) that are hard-coding 
the GCP API keys in their source code.
security_findings.description_intro: The following Google Cloud Platform(GCP) API keys were hard-coded in the App:
security_findings.recommendation:
As GCP API keys are unrestricted by default, adding restrictions to the API keys can prevent unauthorized use. If you are using the 
API key in an Android App, we recommend setting the `Application restriction` to `Android apps`. This setting requires adding the package name of the App and the SHA-1 signing certificate fingerprint. More details on "Application 
restrictions" can be found on [https://cloud.google.com/docs/authentication/api-keys#securing_an_api_key](https://cloud.google.com/docs/authentication/api-keys#securing_an_api_key)

Steps to fix this issue on Google Cloud:

- Go to [https://console.cloud.google.com/apis/credentials](https://console.cloud.google.com/apis/credentials) and select the Firebase project corresponding to the App.
- Upon clicking the project name, you'll be redirected to a page containing all the API keys related to the project.
- The 'restrictions' column lists any restrictions placed on the key. Its default value is often 'None' which isn't good from a security perspective.
- Click on the 'Edit' icon next to the key.
- Under the 'Application restrictions' subheading, select 'Android Apps'.
- Under the 'Restrict usage to your Android apps' subheading, click 'Add an item'.
- Now, enter the package name, certificate fingerprint within the given text fields.
- Click on 'done' to complete the process.

Please note that the Google Cloud Platform UI keeps changing so please use your best judgment while following the above instructions and improvise wherever necessary.

An easy way to verify these settings is by hitting the following URL in the web browser:

```
https://www.googleapis.com/discovery/v1/apis?key=[YOUR_GOOGLE_API_KEY]
```

A properly restricted key will give a '403 Forbidden' response.

A key without sufficient restrictions will give an 'HTTP 200' response along with some JSON data. This implies that anyone who decompiles your APK can use the key for their own purposes. But, if you apply certain restrictions on the console - Google servers will respond only to requests coming from an Android app with a specific package name.
security_findings.title: Google Play Warning: GCP API Keys Exposed in App

security_findings.description:
The account information includes the user's username or email address, used to authenticate to a specific service.

The App can access registered user accounts on the device in the following ways:

* Apps targeting API level `Build.VERSION_CODES.O` and above, will only get list of accounts made visible to it by user 
via the [`newChooseAccountIntent()`](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/accounts/AccountManager#newChooseAccountIntent(android.accounts.Account,%20java.util.List%3Candroid.accounts.Account%3E,%20java.lang.String[],%20java.lang.String,%20java.lang.String,%20java.lang.String[],%20android.os.Bundle)) 
or `AbstractAccountAuthenticator` using [`setAccountVisibility()`](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/accounts/AccountManager#setAccountVisibility(android.accounts.Account,%20java.lang.String,%20int)). 

* Apps targeting API level below `Build.VERSION_CODES.O` that have not been granted the 
`Manifest.permission.GET_ACCOUNTS` permission, will only see those accounts managed by 
`AbstractAccountAuthenticators` whose signature matches the client.

* Apps supporting `Build.VERSION_CODES.LOLLIPOP_MR1` and before, `Manifest.permission.GET_ACCOUNTS` permission is needed 
for those platforms, irrespective of uid or signature match. 

The App can then invoke [`getAccounts()`](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/accounts/AccountManager#getAccounts()) or 
[`getAccountsByType()`](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/accounts/AccountManager#getAccountsByType(java.lang.String))
and retrieve the relevant account details.
security_findings.description_intro: The following locations in the App are accessing registered user accounts:
security_findings.recommendation:
`getAccounts()` and `getAccountsByType()` APIs return personal and sensitive user data and prior to collecting the 
user's accounts the App must clearly disclose the facts to the users. 

Google Play is adding a [new Data privacy and security section](https://support.google.com/googleplay/android-developer/answer/9934569) to the User Data policy where developers 
must provide accurate information related to personal or sensitive user data their apps collect, use, or share. 

As a requirement to this policy, if an App is collecting user accounts and sending it over to the server side, it needs 
to report this action to Google Play and also clearly mention this in the Apps privacy policy.
security_findings.title: App Collects Registered User Accounts

compliance_policy_references.markdown: The application shall use the recommended security headers. (OWASP_ASVS_V_14_4)

security_findings.description:
The HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) header allows the server to inform clients such as browsers or Apps that they should never access the server over HTTP, and that they should automatically convert all attempts to access the site using HTTP to HTTPS requests instead. 

It is supported by all recent browsers and most mobile networking APIs (such as `NSURLSession` on iOS). Hence, setting the HSTS header will ensure that the mobile App is always accessing these endpoints over HTTPS.
security_findings.description_intro: The following mobile endpoints accessed by the App at runtime do not set the HTTP Strict Transport Security header:
security_findings.recommendation:
For endpoints accessed by the App over HTTPS only, set the HTTP Strict Transport Security Header in the endpoints' responses in order to further protect the App's network traffic, and to ensure that the App will connect to the APIs over HTTPS only; the following HTTP header can be added to the endpoint's responses for this purpose:

```
Strict-Transport-Security: max-age=10886400
```

Additionally, and to further secure connections to the endpoints, consider:

* Enabling HSTS for all the endpoint's subdomains using the `includeSubDomains` directive.
* Adding the endpoint to the HSTS preload list, which will automatically enable HSTS for the endpoint in most recent browsers. The process is described in detail at [https://hstspreload.appspot.com/](https://hstspreload.appspot.com/).

This can be achieved by deploying the following HSTS header:

```
Strict-Transport-Security: max-age=10886400; includeSubDomains; preload
```

More information about HSTS is available on [Mozilla's HSTS page](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Security/HTTP_strict_transport_security).
security_findings.title: Server Lacks HTTP Strict Transport Security Header

compliance_policy_references.markdown: Manipulate Device Communication (MTC ID:  APP-1)
The app verifies the X.509 certificate of the remote endpoint (MSTG-NETWORK-3)
Ensure all client messages are sent over encrypted networks, using TLS 1.2 or later. Use up-to-date tools to review the client configuration on a regular basis. (OWASP_ASVS_V_9_1)

security_findings.description:
The vulnerable classes within the App will accept SSL certificates signed by any Certificate Authority (CA) installed within the device's trust store.

As part of a high-profile attack, this could allow an entity in control of a CA private key (such as a government) to perform a man-in-the-middle attack against any HTTPS traffic initiated by the target classes.

Additionally, several trusted Certificate Authorities have been compromised in the past and recently (as described on [Google Security's blog](http://googleonlinesecurity.blogspot.com/2014/07/maintaining-digital-certificate-security.html)) which allowed the attackers to issue malicious but valid SSL certificates for any domain.

Lastly, users can be tricked or required (for example per their employer's policies) to install new CA certificates within the device's trust store, further increasing the potential for compromise.
security_findings.description_intro: The following Java or Kotlin classes within the App use the [`HttpsUrlConnection` Android API](https://developer.android.com/reference/javax/net/ssl/HttpsURLConnection.html) to connect over HTTPS, but do not implement SSL pinning:
security_findings.recommendation:
Rather than using the Android default certificate validation mechanism which trusts dozens of Certificate Authorities by default, implement SSL pinning by embedding the server (or CA) certificate or public key for the App's server endpoints inside the application.

To minimize the development effort required to implement SSL pinning, Data Theorem has released __TrustKit__: an open-source library which makes it very easy to implement SSL pinning in iOS and Android Apps. More information about TrustKit is available at [https://github.com/datatheorem/TrustKit-Android](https://github.com/datatheorem/TrustKit-Android).
security_findings.title: Enable SSL Pinning - HttpsUrlConnection

security_findings.description:
The `ANDROID_ID` is a 64-bit number (as a hex string) that is randomly generated when the user first sets up their device and that remains constant for the lifetime of the device. It can be accessed using the [`Settings.Secure` Android API](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/provider/Settings.Secure.html#ANDROID_ID).

Because the `ANDROID_ID` uniquely identifies a device for its lifetime and does not allow users to opt-out of it or prevent its collection, collecting it has significant privacy implications.

Additionally, the Android ["Best Practices for Unique Identifiers" guide](https://developer.android.com/training/articles/user-data-ids.html) explicitly recommend to not collect the `ANDROID_ID` (referred to as the "SSAID"):

> "#1: Avoid using hardware identifiers. Hardware identifiers such as SSAID (Android ID) and IMEI can be avoided in most use-cases without limiting required functionality."

> "Relying on hardware IDs is discouraged because the user cannot reset them and generally has limited control over their collection."

_Note:_ Google announced changes to several device identifiers in [Android O](https://android-developers.googleblog.com/2017/04/changes-to-device-identifiers-in.html). These changes were done to enhance user privacy and provide more control to users over their device identifiers. In O, Android ID has a different value for each App and each user on the device. Two different Apps on the device will always receive different Android IDs. However, the Android ID will remain the same on App uninstall/reinstall as long as the App's package name and signing key are the same.

This change was introduced to force developers to use the Advertising ID, which is an anonymous string that allows tracking and ad targeting. It is not unique to a device and can be reset by the user at any time.
security_findings.description_intro: The following Java or Kotlin classes within the App are collecting the device's unique `ANDROID_ID`:
security_findings.recommendation:
Discontinue the use of the `ANDROID_ID` in favor of the [Android Advertising ID](https://developers.google.com/android/reference/com/google/android/gms/ads/identifier/AdvertisingIdClient) or [App Set ID](https://developer.android.com/training/articles/app-set-id).

The Advertising ID is a unique, resettable ID tied to the user for advertising purposes, and available via the Google Play Services. It gives users better controls as they can reset the ID or opt-out, and provides developers with a simple, future-proof API to profile users for advertising purposes.

More information about the Advertising ID and possible approaches to identifiers is available in the Android ["Best Practices for Unique Identifiers" guide](https://developer.android.com/training/articles/user-data-ids.html).

It is important to note that, as part of [Google Play Service update in late 2021](https://support.google.com/googleplay/android-developer/answer/6048248?hl=en), 
the Advertising ID will be removed when a user opts out of personalization using Advertising ID in Android Settings. Any attempts to access the identifier will receive a string 
of zeros instead of the identifier. 

Additionally, Apps with target API level set to 31 (Android 12) or later must declare the normal permission `com.google.android.gms.AD_ID` as below in the `AndroidManifest.xml`. 

For essential non ads use-cases such as analytics and fraud prevention, use [App Set ID](https://developer.android.com/training/articles/app-set-id).
security_findings.title: Android ID Collected (GDPR Hardware Tracker)

security_findings.description:
A Subscriber Identification Module (SIM), commonly referred to as a “SIM Card,” includes information about which carrier is associated with the module, its time of manufacture and other carrier-specific information, as well as a serial number uniquely linked with the SIM itself.
SIM Card details may fall in the category of Personally Identifiable Information (PII) and should be collected only with user consent. To retrieve SIM card details, the App needs to have the `Manifest.permission.READ_PHONE_STATE` permissions.
security_findings.description_intro: The following Java or Kotlin classes within the App retrieve the SIM card details:
security_findings.recommendation:
Investigate why the App is collecting the SIM card information and consider removing this functionality from the App to protect the user’s privacy.

The California Department of Justice has produced the [Privacy on the Go report](https://oag.ca.gov/sites/all/files/agweb/pdfs/privacy/privacy_on_the_go.pdf), which strongly recommends limiting the collection of any PII, especially phone numbers and SIM Card details. The report states to use enhanced measures and obtain prior consent from users before accessing personal information such as phone number, email address or name.
security_findings.title: App Collects SIM Card Details

security_findings.description:
Starting with Android 5.0, Google introduced the `android.media.projection` API which allows any third-party App to perform screen capture and screen sharing ([https://developer.android.com/about/versions/android-5.0.html](https://developer.android.com/about/versions/android-5.0.html)). 

Such an App can capture everything on the device’s screen, including sensitive activity from all other Apps such as password keystrokes, credit card data, etc. The capturing ability remains on even if the user terminates/closes the App, but not after a reboot. 

A demo App performing screen capture was developed by Data Theorem's research team and is available at [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tT1XSoykjtA](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tT1XSoykjtA).
security_findings.description_intro: The App does not protect sensitive screens from being displayed in screencasts initiated by third-party Apps. Specifically, the following packages within the App contain vulnerable Activities:

notes.text: we are currently blocking the checkout screen and all of his sub screens
we are currently blocking the checkout screen and all of his sub screens
we are currently blocking the checkout screen and all of his sub screens
we are currently blocking the checkout screen and all of his sub screens

security_findings.recommendation: Protect all sensitive windows within the App by enabling the `FLAG_SECURE` flag. This flag will prevent Apps from being able to record the protected windows. Also, the flag will prevent users from taking screenshots of these windows (by pressing the `VOLUME_DOWN` and `POWER` buttons). As such screenshots are stored on the SDCard by default, they are accessible to all Apps and sensitive data may be exposed.
security_findings.title: Protect App Screens from 3rd Party Apps

compliance_policy_references.markdown: M1 - Improper Platform Usage
The app only requests the minimum set of permissions necessary (MSTG-PLATFORM-1)

security_findings.description:
While many Apps have a valid use case for receiving one or multiple photos from the user, very few need to access the user's entire Photos library, and doing so introduces a large and sensitive data pool to the App. 

Starting with Android 11, Android provides the ability for the user to select a subset of their Photos library for the App to receive, in a manner that doesn't require the App to request a photos permission at all.

By utilizing the [Photo Picker](https://developer.android.com/training/data-storage/shared/photopicker) API, the App can receive a user selection of photos without needless data exposure.
security_findings.description_intro: The App contains the following permission requests which expose the user's entire Photos library:

notes.text: the app requires full access to videos/images for business reasons (i.e. to show the user’s photos in our own pickers/views).

security_findings.recommendation: Migrate from an explicit Photos permission to the Photo Picker API, which does not require the App to declare any Photos permission and which better limits the data exposed to the App.
security_findings.title: Entire Photo Library Exposed to App

security_finding_targets.text: `android.permission.READ_MEDIA_IMAGES`: Allows an application to read photos from external storage.
`android.permission.READ_MEDIA_VIDEO`: Allows an application to read videos from external storage.

compliance_policy_references.markdown: The TLS settings are in line with current best practices, or as close as possible if the mobile operating system does not support the recommended standards (MSTG-NETWORK-2)
Ensure all client messages are sent over encrypted networks, using TLS 1.2 or later. Use up-to-date tools to review the client configuration on a regular basis. (OWASP_ASVS_V_9_1)

security_findings.description_intro: The following Java or Kotlin classes defined within the App define [a custom `X509TrustManager`](https://developer.android.com/reference/javax/net/ssl/X509TrustManager.html) that does not validate SSL certificates:
security_findings.recommendation:
To avoid rejection from Google Play and prevent security issues with the App's SSL/TLS connections, remove any custom `X509TrustManager` defined in the vulnerable classes.

If SSL validation must be customized, ensure that any custom `X509TrustManager` raises a `CertificateException` whenever an SSL certificate does not meet the App’s requirements.
security_findings.title: Google Play Blocker: Unsafe SSL TrustManager Defined

The app verifies the X.509 certificate of the remote endpoint when the secure channel is established. Only certificates signed by a trusted CA are accepted (MSTG-NETWORK-3)
Ensure all client messages are sent over encrypted networks, using TLS 1.2 or later. Use up-to-date tools to review the client configuration on a regular basis. (OWASP_ASVS_V_9_1)

security_findings.description_intro: The following classes within the App define an [insecure `HostnameVerifier`](https://developer.android.com/reference/javax/net/ssl/HostnameVerifier.html#verify(java.lang.String,%20javax.net.ssl.SSLSession)) that disables SSL hostname validation:
security_findings.recommendation:
To avoid rejection from Google Play, ensure the custom `HostnameVerifier` interface returns `false` whenever the hostname of the server does not meet your expectations.

If possible, remove from the vulnerable Java or Kotlin classes any code that customizes hostname validation, in order to use Android's safe default hostname validation logic.
security_findings.title: Google Play Blocker: Unsafe HostnameVerifier Defined

compliance_policy_references.markdown: M5 - Insufficient Cryptography
Access Stored Application Data (MTC ID:  AUT-0)
The app does not rely on symmetric cryptography with hardcoded keys as a sole method of encryption (MSTG-CRYPTO-1)

security_findings.description:
A hard-coded value or a statically computed value is a value that is the same on every execution of your App. 
Statically computed cryptographic values can be extracted from your App and used to attack your App's encrypted data. 
Even if you manipulate keys, initialization vectors, and salts in complex ways before use, they remain unsafe if these 
manipulations are the same for every program execution.

As part of Google's App Security Improvement Program, Google Play has [begun to warn Apps](https://support.google.com/faqs/answer/9450925) that are statically computing cryptographic values.
security_findings.description_intro: Cryptographic secrets - encryption key, salt, or initialization vector(IV) used to encrypt passwords/data are hard-coded in the App's binary. Cryptographic secrets were identified in the following files:
security_findings.recommendation:
Android JetPack's security library contains convenience methods to encrypt data and manage encryption keys securely. 
One such convenience method is `EncryptedSharedPreferences,` which can be used to securely store data without worrying
about the implementation of secret keys, initialization vectors, and salts. 

If your business logic doesn't permit you to use JetPack's security library Google recommends the following standards:

* Secret Keys: Symmetric secret keys must be unpredictable and secret. For encrypting local data, developers should construct secret keys using cryptographically secure randomness (or from user-generated data, if using PBEKeySpecs) and store the secret keys using the AndroidKeystore.

* Initialization Vectors: Initialization vectors must be unique and unpredictable across multiple messages but do not need to be secret. Developers should construct initialization vectors using cryptographically secure randomness. Developers should store or transmit the initialization vectors along with the associated ciphertext.

* Salts: Salts must be unique and unpredictable across multiple hashes but do not need to be secret. Developers should construct salts using cryptographically secure randomness. Developers should store or transmit the salts along with the associated hashes.
security_findings.title: Google Play Warning: Unsafe Cryptographic Encryption

compliance_policy_references.markdown: M1 - Improper Platform Usage
No sensitive data is written to application logs (MSTG-STORAGE-3)

security_findings.description:
Crash Logs provide valuable information to the developers for troubleshooting bugs and get the App up and running again.
However, if the crash log contents are not properly anonymized it may contain sensitive information such as user's 
personal information or tracking identifiers that should never be disclosed to developers or testers in the organization.

An App can choose to implement its own crash log collection mechanism or use one of the several third-party SDKs that 
facilitate capturing and collection of crash logs.
security_findings.description_intro: The following locations in the App are collecting crash logs:

notes.text: Collecting logs for engineering analytics/problem solving is a business requirement, so I believe this should be closed.

security_findings.recommendation:
Properly anonymize the crash logs and redact any sensitive information prior to sending it over to the server side. 

Google Play is adding a [new Data privacy and security section](https://support.google.com/googleplay/android-developer/answer/9934569) to the User Data policy where developers 
must provide accurate information related to personal or sensitive user data their apps collect, use, or share. 

As a requirement to this policy, if an App is collecting crash logs and sending it over to the server side, it needs 
to report this action to Google Play and also clearly mention this in the Apps privacy policy.
security_findings.title: App is Collecting Crash Logs

Configurations for production should be hardened to protect against common attacks, such as debug consoles, raise the bar for Cross-site Scripting (XSS) and Remote File Inclusion (RFI) attacks, and to eliminate trivial information discovery "vulnerabilities" that are the unwelcome hallmark of many penetration testing reports. (OWASP_ASVS_V_14_3)

security_findings.description:
An App can enable debugging of web contents (HTML/CSS/JavaScript) by explicitly setting
[`setWebContentsDebuggingEnabled`](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/webkit/WebView#setWebContentsDebuggingEnabled(boolean)) to `true`. This flag is enabled in order to facilitate 
debugging of web layouts and JavaScript code running inside WebViews. However, when a WebView enables this setting any malicious App on the device can
access data rendered in a WebView. 

WebViews on Android use the [Chrome DevTools Protocol](https://chromedevtools.github.io/devtools-protocol/), which exposes the content on WebViews through Unix domain sockets.
Any App on the device can connect to this socket and retrieve the contents in a WebView.
security_findings.description_intro: The following code locations allow malicious Apps to access sensitive data rendered in a WebView:
security_findings.recommendation:
The ability to debug WebView content is a useful feature to have during the development stages of the App.
However, this setting must be turned off in production. 
By default, `setWebContentsDebuggingEnabled` is set to `false`, to explicitly set it to `true` only in debug builds refer
to the secure code below.
security_findings.title: Debuggable WebViews Allow Malicious Apps to Access Sensitive Data

security_findings.description:
Apps that extract Intents from the Extras field of an untrusted Intent and launch a component by calling `startActivity` 
(or similarly, `startService`) on an extracted Intent can be tricked into launching an unintended private component.
This can lead to either (1) performing sensitive actions with poisoned arguments, and/or (2) having sensitive files stolen through granted URI permissions.

As part of Google's App Security Improvement Program, Google Play has [begun to block Apps](https://support.google.com/faqs/answer/9267555) that are vulnerable to intent redirection.
security_findings.description_intro: The following Java/Kotlin classes redirect an Intent they received from an untrusted App without performing any validation:
security_findings.title: Google Play Blocker: App Vulnerable to Intent Redirection Attacks

compliance_policy_references.markdown: Inform users clearly about the collection and use of personal data, and use it only after opt-in consent
Page 38 / 261

security_findings.description: The app is using permissions related to location, microphone, and/or camera. Starting with Android 12, Android includes a [Privacy Dashboard](https://developer.android.com/about/versions/12/features#privacy-dashboard) to help users stay informed and in control over which apps can access location, microphone, and camera. This rationale will appear on the new Privacy Dashboard screen, your app's permissions screen, or both.
security_findings.recommendation: To avoid looking creepy, [the app should provide a rationale for users to help them understand why your app accesses location, camera, or microphone information](https://developer.android.com/training/permissions/explaining-access). The app should add a new activity with a `START_VIEW_PERMISSION_USAGE` permission in which you decide what your data access rationale activity should show, for example your app's website or a help center article explaining why the app requires those permissions. Depending on which intent filters are used, users see an information icon next to your app's name on certain screens, `VIEW_PERMISSION_USAGE` will allow user to see the app in the system settings and `VIEW_PERMISSION_USAGE_FOR_PERIOD` will allow them to see it in the Privacy Dashboard screen. The user will see that new activity when tapping the app icon in those screens.
security_findings.secure_code:
```
<!-- android:exported required if you target Android 12. -->
<activity android:name=".DataAccessRationaleActivity"
          android:permission="android.permission.START_VIEW_PERMISSION_USAGE"
          android:exported="true">
       <!-- VIEW_PERMISSION_USAGE shows a selectable information icon on
            your app permission's page in system settings.
            VIEW_PERMISSION_USAGE_FOR_PERIOD shows a selectable information
            icon on the Privacy Dashboard screen. -->
    <intent-filter>
       <action android:name="android.intent.action.VIEW_PERMISSION_USAGE" />
       <action android:name="android.intent.action.VIEW_PERMISSION_USAGE_FOR_PERIOD" />
       <category android:name="android.intent.category.DEFAULT" />
       ...
    </intent-filter>
</activity>
```
security_findings.title: Sensitive Permission w/o Justification

additional_contexts.body:

compliance_policy_references.markdown: M5 - Insufficient Cryptography

security_findings.description:
Specifically, these vulnerable classes use the `java.util.Random` class or `Math.random()` method, which are not cryptographically secure and should not be used for any security-sensitive features such as generating unique IDs, passwords or secret keys.
 
The implementation behind these random number generators has weaknesses, such as using the system time as the seed, which could allow an attacker to predict the generator's output.

Lastly, the official Android documentation of the [Random](https://developer.android.com/reference/java/util/Random.html) class recommends using the [SecureRandom](https://developer.android.com/reference/java/security/SecureRandom.html) class instead.
security_findings.description_intro: The following Java or Kotlin classes use an insecure random number generator:

notes.text: there used to be keys all over the app, we consolidate them under a secured file probably an old scan so, I believe we close this ticket

security_findings.recommendation: Within the identified classes, switch to using the [SecureRandom](https://developer.android.com/reference/java/security/SecureRandom) class to get a cryptographically secure random number generator, suitable for use by security-sensitive features.
security_findings.title: Insecure Random Number Generator Usage

compliance_policy_references.markdown: M1 - Improper Platform Usage

security_findings.description:
Third-party code embedded within the App, such as SDKs and open-source libraries, can access all sensitive data the user has granted the App access to by simply invoking the same APIs that the trusted first-party App code uses.

Android allows the App to request access to sensitive data, such as the user's precise location or photos. The user is prompted to grant access to this data under the assumption that the data will be accessible to the App only. The user is entering an implicit contract between themselves and the App. However, when sensitive data access is granted, any third-party code embedded within the App (such as SDKs and other libraries) will also be able to access the sensitive data that the user has granted access to, simply by invoking the same APIs that the trusted first-party App code uses. Without a full source code audit of all third-party and transitive dependencies, which is rarely possible, the App cannot be sure that malicious SDKs are not scraping sensitive data once the user grants access.

[Android 11](https://developer.android.com/about/versions/11/privacy/data-access-auditing) introduces a mechanism to solve this problem: the Sensitive Data Auditing APIs. By utilizing these APIs, the App can register a callback to be invoked each time a sensitive API is accessed. Within this callback, the App can view the context within which the data collection is occurring, which provides valuable insights for developers to determine whether any unauthorized data collection is occurring. The callback also has the ability to block the data collection request entirely.
security_findings.recommendation: Utilize the Sensitive Data Access Auditing APIs to gain confidence into whether any unauthorized data collections are happening within the App due to embedded third-party code. If you identify a third-party SDK surreptitiously collecting data, consider removing the SDK from the App. If desired, utilize the `AppOpsManager` API to block unauthorized data collection entirely.
security_findings.title: App Vulnerable to Permission Riding Attack

compliance_policy_references.markdown: Exploit OS Vulnerability (MTC ID:  APP-26)

security_findings.description:
The App is not leveraging [the SafetyNet Attestation API]((https://developer.android.com/training/safetynet/attestation.html)), a free Google Play service for analyzing the security configuration of a particular device, to determine if it has enabled many of the device-level security features.

In late 2021, Google introduced the [Play Integrity API](https://developer.android.com/google/play/integrity), which is the modern replacement for SafetyNet. Therefore, we have closed this issue and recommend that all applications leverage the Play Integrity API to achieve the same guarantees.

The API uses both software and hardware information from the device to create a profile, which is then compared to a list of device models that have passed Android compatibility testing.

* If the profile of the device is safe, the SafetyNet Attestation API will return `true`
* If the profile of the device is unsafe, the SafetyNet Attestation API will return `false`

Depending on the outcome of the SafetyNet check, an App can either prevent itself from executing or block sensitive APIs from being invoked (such as the "change password" API).

A nonexhaustive list of the SafetyNet checks are below:

* SSL implementation on the device is not standard
* Whether Apps that are not from Google Play can be installed on the device
* Configuration of the default browser is not Chrome
* Configuration of any proxy servers
* The device has been rooted
* Status of SELinux
* SDCard Tampering Tests
* Failure to connect securely to `https://www.google.com`
* Presence of unexpected or unknown Apps running as system
* Presence of SSL Tampering Code
* Failure of DNS checks against `gmail.com`
security_findings.recommendation:
Use the [Play Integrity API](https://developer.android.com/google/play/integrity) to protect the App's flows from compromised devices and installs. The App should use the Play Integrity API to implement the same restrictions as were possible with SafetyNet; for example, the following mechanism could be implemented in the App:

* If the Play Integrity API reports that the environment is legitimate, proceed with the App's regular flow.
* If the Play Integrity API reports that the environment is illegitimate, choose between one of the following options, based on how critical the device's integrity is to the App's security:
  1. Log the failure server-side (for security metrics) and proceed with the App's regular flow.
  2. Log the failure server-side (for security metrics) and prevent sensitive APIs and flows from being accessed (e.g. change password, credit card payment, account transfers, photos access, etc.).
  3. Log the failure server-side (for security metrics) and block any usage of the App.

More information on the Play Integrity API can be found on [the Android developer website](https://developer.android.com/google/play/integrity).
security_findings.title: Enable SafetyNet Attestation API

security_finding_targets.text: The App's lack of enforcement of SafetyNet via `SafetyNet.getClient(this).attest(nonce, API_KEY)`

compliance_policy_references.markdown: "$650.000 Settlement"
California Consumer Privacy Act
Remotely Track Device Without Authorization (MTC ID:  ECO-5, EMM-7)
The app educates the user about the types of personally identifiable information processed (MSTG-STORAGE-12)

Sensitive data and APIs are protected against Insecure Direct Object Reference (IDOR) attacks targeting creation, reading, updating and deletion of records, such as creating or updating someone else's record, viewing everyone's records, or deleting all records. (OWASP_ASVS_V_4_2)
This section helps protect sensitive data from being created, read, updated, or deleted without authorization, particularly in bulk quantities. (OWASP_ASVS_V_8_3)

security_findings.description:
Cellular Network Information is leaking to a 3rd Party OSS/SDK. Information about the device's cellular network, such as the carrier name and country can be used to provide a better user experience when using the App.

However, such data can also be used by third parties to fingerprint the user's device, when combined with other data points (such as the user's location).

During dynamic analysis, Data Theorem’s analyzer checks for leaks in several areas, including, but not limited to, the following items:
OS Version, Device Manufacturer, Device Type, Device Model, Device Name, Device Platform, TimeZone, Locale, Build ID, Bootloader Version, Baseband Version, Fingerprint, MAC Address, IDFA, Android ID, IMEI, IMSI, Phone Number, Carrier Name, Carrier Code, Carrier ID, SIM Serial Number, Local IP Address, SSID, BSSID, etc.

[//]: # "data dump tag"
security_findings.description_intro: The App is leaking information about the device's cellular network to one or more of the following destinations:
security_findings.recommendation:
Due to GDPR and CCPA, any data leaked to 3rd parties that may include user NPI (Nonpublic Personal Information) and PII (Personally Identifiable Information) must be documented in the App’s privacy policy. 

* Option 1: If the OSS/SDK is required, document the data sharing activity above in the App’s privacy policy

* Option 2: If the OSS/SDK is not required, remove it asap and insert the SDK on the “Banned” category within the Policy Configuration menu to avoid future data leaks.
security_findings.title: Cellular Carrier Information Leaked to 3rd Party OSS/SDK

security_findings.description:
The App makes use of libraries and/or frameworks that are licensed under the GNU General Public License. This license allows developers to modify, distribute and commercially use GPL licensed code while requiring developers to include the original license, stating the changes, including the license, copyright and installation instructions as well as disclosing the source of all code that links against the GPL license code (and doing so under a GPL license).

Further reading:
- [Does the GPL require that source code of modified versions be posted to the public?](https://www.gnu.org/licenses/gpl-faq.en.html#GPLRequireSourcePostedPublic)
security_findings.description_intro: The following GPL-Licensed SDKs are used by the App:
security_findings.recommendation:
Consider replacing GPL licensed libraries and/or frameworks with equivalent non-GPL licensed libraries and/or frameworks.

You can visit [https://opensource.org/licenses](https://opensource.org/licenses) to find and read about other popular open source licenses, such as [Apache 2.0](https://opensource.org/licenses/Apache-2.0), [BSD-3-Clause](https://opensource.org/licenses/BSD-3-Clause) and [MIT](https://opensource.org/licenses/MIT).

security_findings.description:
These classes access the IMEI using the `getDeviceId()` method available [within the `TelephonyManager` class](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/telephony/TelephonyManager.html#getDeviceId()).

The IMEI is a hardware identifier that uniquely identifies a mobile phone. Consequently, collecting this identifier may be considered equivalent to tracking users.
security_findings.description_intro: The following Java or Kotlin classes within the App retrieve the device's International Mobile Station Equipment Identity (IMSEI or IMEI):
security_findings.recommendation:
On Android, leverage the Android Advertising ID, more information can be found in [the Google Play Services documentation](https://developer.android.com/google/play-services/id.html).

The Advertising ID is an anonymous identifier for advertising purposes and enables the user to reset their identifier or to opt out of targeted ads within Google Play Apps.

Furthermore, the California Department of Justice has produced the [Privacy on the Go](http://oag.ca.gov/sites/all/files/agweb/pdfs/privacy/privacy_on_the_go.pdf) report, which strongly recommends limiting the collection of any PII, especially unique device identifiers. The report states to move away from the use of unchangeable device-specific identifiers and transition to using app-specific and/or temporary device identifiers.
security_findings.secure_code: A sample project demonstrating how to use the Advertising ID is available on [the Data Theorem GitHub page](https://github.com/datatheorem/AdvertisingID-Android).
security_findings.title: IMEI Hardware Identifier Collected
