security_findings.description:
The App has been compiled to target an older version of the Android SDK, preventing it from leveraging platform improvements and security fixes available in newer versions of Android. Google Play won't accept Apps targeting older SDKs and they won't be visible by devices running a more recent android version.

Please take a note of the following [Google Play deadlines](https://support.google.com/googleplay/android-developer/answer/11926878)

* _August 31, 2023_: Apps must target **API level 33**. 

Google has published a [Migration Guide](https://developer.android.com/distribute/best-practices/develop/target-sdk.html) that lists improvements and changes in various versions of Android. 
We recommend taking a look at this guide while updating the SDK version. 

As an example, the sample list below highlights some of the newer security issues from various Android releases:

* API Level 17 (Android 4.2): The export option is set to “false” by default for Android components, which prevents any third-party App from targeting components in your App.
* API Level 21 (Android 5.0): WebViews will no longer load mixed-mode content (HTTP and HTTPS), unlike all previous versions of Android.
* API Level 26 (Android 8.0): Insecure TLS fallback for network connections [has been disabled](https://android-developers.googleblog.com/2017/04/android-o-to-drop-insecure-tls-version.html).
* API Level 28 (Android 9): New foreground service permission and network TLS enabled by default [see android 9 changes](https://developer.android.com/about/versions/pie/android-9.0-changes-28).
* API Level 30 (Android 11): Scoped storage enforcement [see android 11 changes](https://developer.android.com/about/versions/11).
* API Level 31 (Android 12): Bluetooth and location stricter permissions [see android 12 changes](https://developer.android.com/about/versions/12).
* API Level 33 (Android 13): `sharedUserId` removal [see android 13 changes](https://developer.android.com/about/versions/13).
security_findings.description_intro: The following `targetSdkVersion` of the App is outdated. It won't be visible to new users and Google may delist the app from the Play Store per app store policies.
security_findings.recommendation:
Set the Target SDK value to the most recent version of Android. Later versions of Android often address security issues from previous versions, and also provide new APIs that can be used for security. 
More information is available in [the Android developer documentation](http://developer.android.com/intl/ko/guide/topics/manifest/uses-sdk-element.html#target)
security_findings.secure_code:
Set the target SDK value to the most recent version of Android:

```
android:targetSdkVersion="33"
```
security_findings.title: Google Play Blocker: App Target SDK is Outdated

compliance_policy_references.markdown: M1 - Improper Platform Usage
CWE-926 - Improper Export of Android Application Components

security_findings.description:
Any malicious App on the device can attack an App's exported `activities`, `services`, or `broadcast receivers` (components) to gain access 
to sensitive information, modify the internal state of the App or trick a user into interacting with the victim App 
while believing they are still interacting with the malicious App.

An Android component that defines intent filters is automatically exported unless it explicitly sets the 
`android:exported` attribute to `false`. 

To prevent Apps from inadvertently exporting a component, [Google Play has made it mandatory in Android 12](https://developer.android.com/about/versions/12/behavior-changes-12#exported) to specify the `android:exported` attribute.

If the App targets Android 12 or higher and contains `activities`, `services`, or `broadcast receivers` (components) 
that use intent filters, it must explicitly declare the `android:exported` attribute for these App components. 

Apps that don't explicitly declare the `android:exported` for components with intent filters can't be installed on a 
device that runs Android 12 or higher.
security_findings.description_intro: The following components declared in the `AndroidManifest.xml` file do not define the `android:exported` attribute and may be exposed to harmful Apps on the device:
security_findings.recommendation:
For the reported components define an explicit value for the `android:exported` attribute. 

Developers using Android Studio 2020.3.1 Canary 11 or later to build Apps will see the following lint message in the 
`AndroidManifest.xml` file. 

*    ```When using intent filters, please specify android:exported as well```

Additionally, compilation of the App fails with the following message:


*   ```Manifest merger failed : Apps targeting Android 12 and higher are required to specify an explicit value for android:exported when the corresponding component has an intent filter defined.```
security_findings.secure_code:
```
<service android:name="com.example.app.backgroundService"
         android:exported="false">
    <intent-filter>
        <action android:name="com.example.app.START_BACKGROUND" />
    </intent-filter>
</service>
```
security_findings.title: Google Play Blocker: Exported Attribute Missing on App Components

security_findings.description:
According to the Android developer guidelines, the `getRunningAppProcesses()` method was intended for debugging and/or presenting a task management user interface. However, it can also be used to determine which other Apps the user has run on their device.

As of 2014, Google began classifying Apps that collect the list of Apps on the device as Spyware, as described on page 29 of the [2014 Android Security Report](https://source.android.com/security/reports/Google_Android_Security_2014_Report_Final.pdf): 

> "Throughout 2014, we have regularly tightened the definition of Spyware, for example in 2014 we began to classify applications that send the list of other applications on the device as Spyware."

Lastly, a list of SDKs that have already been blocked by Google Play because of this issue can be found [here](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/27044517/notification-from-google-play-store).
security_findings.description_intro: The following Java or Kotlin classes defined within the App collect the list of running Apps on the device using the [`ActivityManager.getRunningAppProcesses()` method](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/app/ActivityManager.html):
security_findings.recommendation:
Due to its deprecation, do not use the `getRunningAppProcesses()` method on production builds. If the method is being used for debugging purposes, safely use it on preproduction builds only.

Furthermore, on API level 23 and later, the `getRunningAppProcesses` method only returns the current App’s process, instead of all the running processes (including processes that belong to other Apps).
security_findings.title: List of Running Apps Collected - getRunningAppProcesses

security_findings.description:
Wi-Fi Network Information is being leaked to a 3rd Party OSS/SDK. Information about the device's Wi-Fi network, such as the SSID the device is connected to or the device's local IP address can be used by an App to communicate with devices on the local network, or to set up complex network streams such as videoconferencing calls.

Details about the user's device, such as the screen size or the OS version are generally used to provide stats about the App's user base, and to improve the App's user experience.
However, such data can also be used by third parties to fingerprint the user's device, when combined with other data points (such as the user's location).

During dynamic analysis, Data Theorem’s analyzer checks for leaks in several areas, including, but not limited to, the following items:
OS Version, Device Manufacturer, Device Type, Device Model, Device Name, Device Platform, TimeZone, Locale, Build ID, Bootloader Version, Baseband Version, Fingerprint, MAC Address, IDFA, Android ID, IMEI, IMSI, Phone Number, Carrier Name, Carrier Code, Carrier ID, SIM Serial Number, Local IP Address, SSID, BSSID, etc.

[//]: # "data dump tag"
security_findings.description_intro: The App is leaking information about the device's Wi-Fi network to one or more of the following destinations:
security_findings.recommendation:
Due to GDPR and CCPA, any data leaked to 3rd parties that may include user NPI (Nonpublic Personal Information) and PII (Personally Identifiable Information) must be documented in the App’s privacy policy. 

* Option 1: If the OSS/SDK is required, document the data sharing activity above in the App’s privacy policy

* Option 2: If the OSS/SDK is not required, remove it asap and insert the SDK on the “Banned” category within the Policy Configuration menu to avoid future data leaks.
security_findings.title: Device Wi-Fi Information Leaked to 3rd Party OSS/SDK

security_findings.description:
The [TestFairy](https://testfairy.com/) SDK embedded within the App records the device screen for the duration of the App's session, and sends the data to a remote server without user consent. The recorded sessions may include PII/PHI data, such as credit card numbers, passwords, social security numbers, medical health data, etc. 

TestFairy is a legitimate SDK that helps developers manage the beta testing process for their Apps (distribution to internal teams, collecting logs, soliciting user feedback, etc.). While these features help developers improve their Apps, the "Video Recording" may expose sensitive/confidential data to a third-party vendor, TestFairy. Additionally, and depending on the App's content, recording without permission could also be a compliance violation.
security_findings.recommendation:
While TestFairy session recordings are a valuable development and debugging resource, the privacy violations it introduces are unsuitable for a production environment. Hence, the SDK should either be removed from the App or, if its functionality is needed, it should be enabled in development builds only, as shows in the Secure Code section.

Please note while the SDK records all live sessions, organizations need to upgrade to the Enterprise edition to have access to any data that has already been recorded.

[//]: # "data dump tag"
security_findings.title: TestFairy SDK Records and Exports Live User Sessions

security_findings.description:
The MAC address is a hardware identifier that uniquely identifies a device and does not change across device resets. Consequently, collecting this information may be considered equivalent to tracking users.

Additionally, and due to the privacy implications, Android 6.0 (Marshmallow) no longer allows Apps to retrieve the device's MAC address. Specifically, the `WifiInfo.getMacAddress()` and `BluetoothAdapter.getAddress()` methods will only return a constant, fake address of 02:00:00:00:00:00. This change was implemented in order to prevent Apps from using the MAC address to track users.
security_findings.description_intro: The following Java or Kotlin classes within the App retrieve WiFi SSIDs and the device's MAC address:
security_findings.recommendation:
Do not collect hardware-specific identifiers (MAC, SSID, UDID, IMEI, IMSI, Apple IDs, Android IDs, unique series numbers) from the device. Leverage existing and safe identifiers from Apple (IDFV) and Google (Advertising ID).

On Android, leverage [the Android Advertising ID](https://support.google.com/googleplay/android-developer/answer/6048248?hl=en), which is an anonymous identifier for advertising purposes only. It enables the user to reset their identifier or to opt-out of targeted ads within Google Play Apps.

Furthermore, the California Department of Justice has produced the Privacy on the Go report, which strongly recommends limiting the collection of any PII, especially unique device identifiers. The report states to move away from the use of unchangeable device-specific identifiers and transition to using temporary identifiers that are only tied to the App and not the whole device.
security_findings.secure_code: The following Secure Code demonstrates how to leverage the Advertising ID within an Android App: [https://github.com/datatheorem/AdvertisingID-Android](https://github.com/datatheorem/AdvertisingID-Android).
security_findings.title: WiFi MAC Address / SSID Collected

security_findings.description:
According to the Android developer guidelines, the `getRunningServices()` method was intended for debugging and/or presenting a task management user interface. However, it can also be used to determine which other Apps the user has run on their device.

As of 2014, Google began classifying Apps that collect the list of Apps on the device as Spyware, as described on page 29 of the [2014 Android Security Report](https://source.android.com/security/reports/Google_Android_Security_2014_Report_Final.pdf): 

> "Throughout 2014, we have regularly tightened the definition of Spyware, for example in 2014 we began to classify applications that send the list of other applications on the device as Spyware."

Lastly, a list of SDKs that have already been blocked by Google Play because of this issue can be found [here](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/27044517/notification-from-google-play-store).
security_findings.description_intro: The following Java or Kotlin classes defined within the App collect the list of running Apps on the device using the [`ActivityManager.getRunningServices()` method](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/app/ActivityManager.html):
security_findings.recommendation: Do not use the `getRunningServices()` method on production builds. If the method is being used for debugging purposes, safely use it on preproduction builds only.
security_findings.title: List of Running Apps Collected - getRunningServices

security_findings.description:
Accessing user's files without user consent is a privacy violation.  
The user's files are one of the sensitive stores of content on the device. To follow the principle of least privilege, the App should request the minimum access permissions necessary to fulfill its functionality.

An Android App can access files via the following methods:

* [Media Store Framework](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/provider/MediaStore): 
This framework provides and optimized index into media collections, that allows for retrieving and 
updating media files. It provides a rich set of APIs to perform CRUD operations on files. 
MediaStore API is a recommended way to go when working with media files (pictures, audio, video)

Note: On Android 10 and above, in order to access files that were created by other Apps, you need to 
request the `READ_EXTERNAL_STORAGE` permission. 

Also, if the user uninstalls and then installs your app again, you must request `READ_EXTERNAL_STORAGE` to access the files 
that your app originally created. This permission request is required because the system considers the file to be 
attributed to the previously installed version of the app, rather than the newly installed one.

* [File API](https://developer.android.com/reference/java/io/File) or Native libraries, such as `fopen()`. 

* [Storage Access Framework](https://developer.android.com/guide/topics/providers/document-provider). 
The Storage Access Framework lets the user select which file the App can get access to at runtime. 
You also don’t need any permissions if you’re trying to obtain any documents or other types of content when using 
Storage Access Framework. That’s because a user is involved in the process of selecting the actual content to work with.
security_findings.description_intro: The following locations in the App are accessing files and documents in device's shared storage:
security_findings.recommendation:
Make sure the App accesses user's files upon user consent. 

A privacy friendly way of accessing user's media content is via the [Storage Access Framework](https://developer.android.com/guide/topics/providers/document-provider) (SAF).

In the SAF flow, for an app to get access, it makes a request to the OS, which then displays a directory chooser screen. 
On this screen the user selects the root of a folder hierarchy in which that app will be able to read and write files.

SAF lets the user control storage access on a more granular level. The user can now choose which files or directories 
the App can access.
security_findings.title: App Accesses Files and Documents from Shared Storage

security_findings.description:
User Names fall in the category of Personally Identifiable Information (PII) and should be collected only with user 
consent. 

However, leaking user's name to third party SDKs or domains is considered a privacy violation and can leave your 
consumer information open to tracking, phishing and fraud. 

During dynamic analysis, Data Theorem’s analyzer checks for leaks in several areas, including, but not limited to, the following items:
CreditCard number, DebitCard numbers, Bank Routing numbers, Credit Score, Social Security Numbers, Physical Address, 
Email Address, Username.

security_findings.description_intro: The App is leaking the user's name to one or more of the following destinations:
security_findings.recommendation:
Due to GDPR and CCPA, any data leaked to 3rd parties that may include user NPI (Nonpublic Personal Information) and 
PII (Personally Identifiable Information) must be documented in the App’s privacy policy. 

* Option 1: If the OSS/SDK is required, document the data sharing activity above in the App’s privacy policy

* Option 2: If the OSS/SDK is not required, remove it asap and insert the SDK on the “Banned” category within the 
Policy Configuration menu to avoid future data leaks.

Additionally, Google Play is adding a [new Data privacy and security section](https://support.google.com/googleplay/android-developer/answer/9934569) to the User Data policy where developers 
must provide accurate information related to personal or sensitive user data their apps collect, use, or share. 

As a requirement to this policy, if an App is collecting user's financial numbers and sending it over to the server side, it needs 
to report this action to Google Play and also clearly mention this in the Apps privacy policy.
security_findings.title: App Collects User's Default Name on Device

security_findings.description:
The `MediaStore.setRequireOriginal(photoUri)` API provides access to the raw image data, also known as EXIF, which includes additional sensitive information such as the location where the photo was taken, the device details and the time the photo was taken. To call this API the App needs to list the `ACCESS_MEDIA_LOCATION` permission in its manifest file. However, `ACCESS_MEDIA_LOCATION` is not a runtime permission and is automatically granted upon installation. In most cases the user is unaware that the App is requesting this permission.

Using EXIF data to extract location is deceptive because it circumvents the standard Android UI prompt for location access, falsely leading users to believe that only image data is being used.
security_findings.description_intro: The following code locations within the App extract user's private information via EXIF information in user's private photos:
security_findings.recommendation:
Don’t access the EXIF data unless there is a clear business requirement and the user approves the App’s need for accessing this data.

If you need device location events, use Android's [Location API](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/location/Location), which appropriately conveys the privacy risk when used.
security_findings.title: Data Privacy Breached via Image EXIF Extraction

The app only requests the minimum set of permissions necessary (MSTG-PLATFORM-1)

security_findings.description:
The App is requesting permission to write data to the device's SD card via the following entry in its Android Manifest: 

`<uses-permission android:name="android.permission.WRITE_EXTERNAL_STORAGE" />`

External SD cards on Android devices do not have any file permission protection, allowing attackers, third-party Apps, or even malware to access the data at any time. 

Furthermore, Ransomware Apps are known to gather all data on the SD Card, encrypt the data in full, and then demand payment from the user to decrypt the data. 

Finally, any data stored on the external SD card is not erased even if the mobile device is wiped.
security_findings.recommendation:
Always use App's internal storage for any file, as storing App data to the SD card is strongly discouraged, unless it is known to be public information accessible to all.

The [internal storage](http://developer.android.com/training/basics/data-storage/files.html) has the following properties:

* It's always available.
* By default, files saved here are accessible by the App only.
* When the user uninstalls the App, the system removes all the App's files from internal storage.
security_findings.title: Write Access Requested to SD Card Storage

security_findings.description:
As of 2014, Google began classifying Apps that collect the list of Apps on the device as Spyware, as described on page 29 of the [2014 Android Security Report](https://source.android.com/security/reports/Google_Android_Security_2014_Report_Final.pdf): 

> "Throughout 2014, we have regularly tightened the definition of Spyware, for example in 2014 we began to classify applications that send the list of other applications on the device as Spyware."

Additionally, popular Apps such as Twitter have been heavily criticized for collecting this data [Twitter Is Going to Spy on You](http://www.forbes.com/sites/ianmorris/2014/11/27/twitter-is-going-to-spy-on-you-via-the-apps-you-install-heres-how-to-stop-it/#28a031274eaa).


Android 11 (API 30) introduced [Package Visibility](https://developer.android.com/training/basics/intents/package-visibility) which drastically reduces the data returned by the `getInstalledApplications` API:

1. Apps now need to define the [`<queries>` element](https://developer.android.com/training/basics/intents/package-visibility#package-name) in their manifest file. Only package names listed in the `<queries>` element can be queried by the App via the `getInstalledApplications` API.

2. The[`QUERY_ALL_PACKAGES` permission](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/Manifest.permission#QUERY_ALL_PACKAGES) is useful in the rare cases that your App might need to query or interact with all installed Apps on a device, independent of the components they contain. However, unnecessary usage of this permission may result in a Google Play Store Rejection.
security_findings.description_intro: The following Java or Kotlin classes defined in the App collect the list of installed Apps on the device using the [`PackageManager.getInstalledApplications()` method](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/content/pm/PackageManager.html#getInstalledApplications(int)):
security_findings.recommendation:
Disable the App's ability to collect the list installed Apps on the device; this will help to ensure that the App is not flagged as Spyware by Google.

In the vast majority of cases, it's possible to fulfill your App's use cases by interacting with the set of [Apps that are visible automatically](https://developer.android.com/training/basics/intents/package-visibility#automatic) and by [declaring the other Apps that your app needs to access](https://developer.android.com/training/basics/intents/package-visibility#declare-other-apps) in the manifest file.
To respect user privacy, your App should request the smallest amount of package visibility necessary in order for your App to work.

If your App targets Android 11 (API level 30) or higher and needs to interact with Apps other than the ones that are visible automatically, add the `<queries>` element in your App's `AndroidManifest.xml`.
Within the `<queries>` element, [specify the other Apps by package name](https://developer.android.com/training/basics/intents/package-visibility#package-name), by [Intent Filter Signature](https://developer.android.com/training/basics/intents/package-visibility#intent-signature), or by [Provider Authority](https://developer.android.com/training/basics/intents/package-visibility#provider-authority).
security_findings.secure_code:
```
// Secure code to Query and interact with specific packages
<manifest package="com.example.game">
    <queries>
        <package android:name="com.example.store" />
        <package android:name="com.example.services" />
    </queries>
    ...
</manifest>

// Secure code to Query and interact with Apps given an Intent Filter
<manifest package="com.example.game">
    <queries>
        <intent>
            <action android:name="android.intent.action.SEND" />
            <data android:mimeType="image/jpeg" />
        </intent>
    </queries>
    ...
</manifest>

// Secure code to Query and interact with Apps given a Provider Authority
<manifest package="com.example.suite.enterprise">
    <queries>
        <provider android:authorities="com.example.settings.files" />
    </queries>
    ...
</manifest>
```
security_findings.title: List of Installed Apps Collected - getInstalledApplications

security_findings.description:
The App is allowed to run even if Android's "Verify Apps" mechanism has been disabled on the device.

Verify Apps is a free Android utility that regularly checks for Potentially Harmful Apps (aka malware). When enabled, Verify Apps reviews each App during installation and also monitors App behavior afterward, in order to block harmful activity.

In the various situations, the user may download and sideload Apps outside of Google Play, on their device:

* APKs directly downloaded from the Internet.
* APKs available on third-party App Stores, especially in countries where Google Play is not available (such as China).

Such Apps haven't received the security vetting of Google Play, and Verify Apps can provide the device with a similar level of App vetting. Hence, requiring Verify Apps to be enabled ensures that the third-party Apps on the device are not harmful and will not try to attack the mobile App.
security_findings.recommendation:
When the App is started, ensure that the user's device has enabled Verify Apps. If Verify Apps has not been enabled, redirect the user to the Security settings of the device in order to enable Verify Apps.

By ensuring Verify Apps is enabled, the mobile App has a stronger level of protection from third party Apps on the device.
security_findings.title: Enable Android Verify Apps

security_finding_targets.text: The App's lack of enforcement of VerifyApps via `SafetyNet.getClient(this).isVerifyAppsEnabled()`

security_findings.recommendation:
Google has released [security patches](https://source.android.com/security/bulletin/2020-05-01) for Android 8 and 9. Provided the security patches are installed, 
updating the minimum SDK version of the App to 26 (Android 8) will make sure the App will not run on vulnerable versions of Android.

Alternatively, the App can mark the `launchMode` of the Launcher/Main Activity in the AndroidManifest file as `singleTask` or `singleInstance`.
However, these launch modes are *not* recommended for general use and please *exercise caution* when using them. 
For example, one side effect is the App will always start in the launcher Activity instead of where the user left off; thus, the App flows need to be thoroughly tested with these changes.

security_findings.description:
Unpatched versions of Android 8 and 9 and vulnerable to [CVE-2018-9492](https://www.cvedetails.com/cve/CVE-2018-9492/): Privilege Escalation Vulnerability in [`ActivityManagerService.java`](https://android.googlesource.com/platform/frameworks/base/+/962fb40991f15be4f688d960aa00073683ebdd20).
This vulnerability allows any third party malicious App to access private data of a victim App without any user interaction. 

Any third party App can acquire read/write access to any ContentProvider in the victim App. It doesn't matter if the ContentProvider is exported/non-exported or if the ContentProvider is protected with permissions. 

[Security patches](https://source.android.com/security/bulletin/2018-10-01) were released by Google in 2018 to mitigate this vulnerability. Majority of the devices should be patched by now. However, it is possible that some device manufacturers may not have pushed these updates to the users or that some users may have chosen to not install the security updates, leaving a very small percentage of users vulnerable to this issue.
security_findings.description_intro: The following Content Providers within the App are vulnerable to Permission Bypass Vulnerability:
security_findings.recommendation:
This issue is a vulnerability in the Android OS and can't be exploited on a patched version of Android. 
However, if you are concerned about unpatched devices, the following options can be used to mitigate the vulnerability:

Option 1: Validate the App requesting for access to the ContentProvider. 

Get the calling App's package name via the [`getCallingPackage()`](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/content/ContentProvider#getCallingPackage()) API. 
You can use this information to validate that the recipient is allowed to receive the data.

Option 2: Set `minSdkVersion` to at least `29` for your application.

This vulnerability affects unpatched versions of Android 8 and 9 (API level 26 to 28), by setting the `minSdkVersion` to 29 your App will install only on devices running Android 10 and above.
However, please note that doing so will cause your App not to work on a majority of Android devices.
security_findings.title: Privilege Escalation via Content Provider (CVE-2018-9492)

security_findings.description:
Due to an Android OS issue, the task stack of your App is vulnerable to Activity Injection from a 3rd Party malicious App on the user’s device. The exploit occurs when the user clicks on the icon of your App; however, the injected malicious Activity is shown instead. The malicious Activity can now perform a phishing attack on any App installed on the device.

A malicious App can execute this attack by taking advantage of a flaw in the Android task management architecture. By default, the Android task management architecture places all Activities of an App in the same task stack. The name of this task stack is usually the package name of the App; however, Android provides various task management options wherein an App can change this default behavior. A malicious App can leverage these task management options to create a malicious Activity in the task stack of a target App and perform an Activity hijacking attack.

All versions of the Android OS ranging between Android 3.x to Android 10 are susceptible to the issue caused by this vulnerable task management approach. The Activity Hijacking attack that takes advantage of Android's task management architecture was first reported at the [Usenix Security Conference](https://www.usenix.org/system/files/conference/usenixsecurity15/sec15-paper-ren-chuangang.pdf) in 2015.  Most recently in Dec 2019, the security firm [Promon](https://promon.co/security-news/strandhogg/) named this issue - *Strandhogg*, since then this issue has been receiving more attention from the media and bug-bounty researchers.

The main components that the user interacts with when working with an App are the Activities. An Activity provides the window in which the App draws its UI. Different Activities get launched when the user explores different features of the App. All these launched Activities are stored on the Task Stack. Each time a new screen is opened, a new instance of Activity is created and placed by the system at the top of this stack.

Android's task stack allows Activities from third party Apps to be placed along with the Activities of the running App. This enables Apps to launch other Apps to handle a particular functionality like choosing an image or opening a PDF. Thus, when an Activity from a third party App is launched it is placed on the Task Stack. Pressing the back button will take the user back to the original App. This allows for seamless integration.

An important option that the Android Task Management system provides is `TaskAffinity`. `TaskAffinity` specifies the affinity of the Activity for a specific task. By default, the TaskAffinity for all Activities in an App is the App's package name (bundle/application ID). However, this can be set to any value the App developer desires. If the developer explicitly specifies the `taskAffinity` value, she can force the Activity to start within an arbitrary task. 

A malicious App can define an Activity with custom `taskAffinity` and `allowTaskReparenting` attributes.


```
<activity
android:name="com.attacker.maliciousactivity"
android:taskAffinity="com.example.targetapp"
android:allowTaskReparenting="true"/>
```

By assigning these specially crafted values the Malicious App is able to carry the Activity Hijacking or Strandhogg attack. In this attack the Android OS brings the Malicious App’s Activity to the foreground when the user clicks on the Target App's icon.

The Attack works as follows: The `allowTaskReparenting` attribute tells the Android system that when a new Task Stack with `taskAffinity` - "`com.example.targetApp`" appears in the system, the "`maliciousactivity`" is immediately moved to the top of this new Task Stack. Now when the user clicks on the TargetApp's icon the `maliciousactivity` is brought to the foreground. This is shown in the below screenshot.
security_findings.recommendation:
* Google has released [security patches](https://source.android.com/security/bulletin/android-11) for Android 11. Provided the security patches are installed, 
updating the minimum SDK version of the App to 30 (Android 11) will make sure the App will not run on vulnerable versions of Android.
  
* Alternatively, the App can set the `taskAffinity` of all Activities to “”(an empty string) in the `application` tag of `AndroidManifest.xml` to indicate the activities of the benign App do not have an affinity to any task. Note: Please make sure you thoroughly test the App as this solution may interfere with the app's flow.

Researchers haven't found Malicious Apps exploiting this vulnerability on the Google Play Store. However, there have been several reports of this vulnerability being exploited on third party App Stores and side-loaded Apps.

DataTheorem's intention of including this issue was to make our customers aware of this issue. You may choose not to fix this and rely on the security provided by the Google Play Store as a compensating control.
security_findings.secure_code:
```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<manifest xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
    package="com.datatheorem.android.tjservice">
    ...
    <application
        android:allowBackup="true"
        ...
        android:theme="@style/AppTheme">
        <activity
            android:name=".MainActivity"
            android:label="@string/app_name"
            android:theme="@style/AppTheme.NoActionBar"
            android:taskAffinity="">
            <intent-filter>
                <action android:name="android.intent.action.MAIN" />
                <category android:name="android.intent.category.LAUNCHER" />
            </intent-filter>
        </activity>
        ...
```
